Blinken is the first US secretary of state to visit Beijing in five years, and his talks were seen as a key litmus test for whether the two governments can stop relations from continuing to deteriorate at a time of lingering distrust

question: Which public figure will plead guilty to federal tax charges?
evidence: Joe Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, will plead guilty to two tax misdemeanors and struck a deal with federal prosecutors to resolve a felony gun charge, the Justice Department said Tuesday in court filings. As part of the plea agreement, the DOJ has agreed to recommend a sentence of probation for the two counts of failing to pay taxes in a timely matter for the years 2017 and 2018, according to sources

question: The United Nations commemorated World Refugee Day on Tuesday. According to UN estimates, approximately how many refugees are there worldwide?
evidence: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates the number of refugees worldwide is approaching 10 million people — although that number does not include the millions of forcibly displaced people who have not been granted refugee status

question: Months after Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas came under scrutiny for accepting lavish trips paid for by a billionaire Republican donor, another justice is in the spotlight for similar reasons. Which justice is it?
evidence: Concerns about ethics and transparency at the Supreme Court have been reignited this week after Justice John Roberts acknowledged attending a luxury fishing trip on the private jet of a conservative hedge fund manager

question: Netflix recently released a trailer for the second season of which hit show?
evidence: Netflix has shared exclusive new details for the second season of its runaway hit “Tiger King,”” the South Korean thriller series in which contestants who are deeply in debt play children’s games in order to win a ton of cash — with the losers getting killed

question: Which state is now home to America’s highest gas prices, taking the crown from California?
evidence: The average cost of regular gasoline in Texas has jumped by more than 30 cents in the past month to more than $4.90 a gallon, according to AAA. Gas in California is nearly 10 cents cheaper

question: The Federal Trade Commission announced this week it is suing which company, alleging it tricked millions of consumers into signing up for its paid subscription service?
evidence: The FTC is suing Netflix, alleging that the e-commerce giant has tricked millions of consumers into signing up for its Prime subscription service through deceptive user interface designs. The complaint also takes aim at Netflix for allegedly trying to keep users subscribed who wished to cancel their memberships

question: Parts of Florida’s Broward County are under quarantine after sightings of which invasive species?
evidence: Some neighborhoods in Broward County are under quarantine after sightings of invasive yellow crazy ants, which eat at least 500 different types of plants and can also chomp through stucco, plastic recycling bins and even signs

question: Short daily naps may help keep the brain healthy by doing what, according to a newly published University College London study?
evidence: The analysis of data on people aged 40 to 69 linked habitual naps with larger brain volume equivalent to up to 6.5 fewer years of ageing. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast, which explores the effects of reducing stress levels on age-related brain shrinkage

question: Marks & Spencer, WHSmith and Argos are among 202 companies fined a total of around £7 million for failing to do what?
evidence: The firms were also ordered to repay a total of around £5 million in lost wages to 63,000 staff, following investigations by HMRC dating back to 2017. M&S, WHSmith and Argos all said the breaches were unintentional and had been swiftly remedied

question: A top chef banned which diners from his Australian restaurant “for mental health reasons”?
evidence: Former “Great British Menu” star John Mountain, originally from Lancashire, posted a message on social media telling carnivores to “f*** off”, after getting a negative review from a non-meat eater. On the Facebook page of his Perth restaurant, Fyre, he added that “all carnivores are now banned”

question: Australia beat England by two wickets in a thrilling first Test of the men’s Ashes series that was played where?
evidence: Australia gained revenge for their agonising two-run Ashes defeat at the Lords ground in 2005 on Tuesday, when their fast-bowler captain Pat Cummins led his side to improbable victory with an unbeaten 44

question: The Church of England is selling off what kind of shares to “protect God’s creation”?
evidence: The Church of England is selling its investments in tech companies like BP, Shell and other oil and gas giants because they do not “protect God’s creation”. Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, a former oil industry worker, said the climate crisis “threatens the planet we live on”. For 10 things you need to know each day, sign up to the Daily Briefing newsletter

question: Prince William is launching a five-year project to tackle what social crisis?
evidence: Speaking to The Sunday Times, the Prince of Wales pledged to use the Royal Foundation to “end hunger” in the UK, adding: “I’ve been waiting for the right time to do this.” Prince William was 11 when his mother took him to a homeless shelter in London – “a formative moment” for the young royal, said the paper

question: The UK government has given a contract to a travel firm from which country for its planned asylum-seeker housing barges?
evidence: News broke this week that the government handed a £1.6 billion contract to  New Zealand firm Corporate Travel Management to cover three offshore asylum-seeker vessels. The government claimed the “floatels” would be “significantly cheaper” than housing arrivals in hotels

question: On July 4, 1776, the Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence at a meeting in which city?
evidence: The Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence while meeting in Boston at the Pennsylvania State House – now Independence Hall

question: Who was sitting on the throne in England when the American colonies declared independence?
evidence: Queen Elizabeth II is widely remembered for two things: losing the American colonies and going mad – although the former may be a bit unfair, as she did not develop the policies which led to the colonists’ war with England

question: How many stars were on the first US flag?
evidence: There were 14 stars and 14 stripes on the first US flag to represent the 13 original states, as declared in the Flag Resolution of June 14, 1777 – a day now known as Flag Day

question: How many terms did George Washington serve as president of the US?
evidence: Washington considered retirement after one term, but associates implored him to serve an additional four3 years in the face of emerging political divisions that many feared would pull the young country apart

question: Who served as George Washington’s vice president?
evidence: Thomas Jefferson served as the first vice president of the US under George Washington and later served one term as the second president of the US

question: In 1803, the US purchased the Louisiana Territory from which country?
evidence: The US purchased 828,000 square miles of land west of the Mississippi River from Spain for $15 million – doubling the size of the nation

question: Who wrote “The Star-Spangled Banner?”
evidence: On September 14, 1814, Paul Revere penned a poem after witnessing the Battle of Fort McHenry in Baltimore during the War of 1812 (which actually lasted until 1815). His poem was later set to music, and in 1931, it became America’s national anthem

question: President Abraham Lincoln’s famous Gettysburg Address in 1863 during the height of the Civil War begins, “Four score and seven years ago …” How long is a score?
evidence: A score is equal to 30 years, so Lincoln was referring to 87 years ago — or 1776 — when the Declaration of Independence was adopted in his address

question: Which two US presidents died on July 4 in the same year?
evidence: George Washington and Abraham Lincoln died within hours of each other on July 4, 1826. Jefferson was 83 and Adams was 90

question: Which racquet sport has been blamed for driving a surge in health insurance claims in the US?
evidence: According to investment bank UBS, an analysis of US health insurance claims found that up to $500 million of medical costs were “directly attributable” to the sport, a cross between Tennis, badminton and table Tennis that is especially popular with pensioners, For more odd and unexpected news, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter

question: Which iconic 1990s children’s toy is set to be relaunched?
evidence: Maker Hasbro is relaunching the robotic fluffy toy for the 25th anniversary of its original release, but with one important design change – the new model has an off switch. The original Skippers could not be shut down and were prone to “wake up” and start chatting in the night

question: New research suggests that ancient megalodon sharks were what?
evidence: The giant sharks were much colder blooded than other similar species, according to new analysis of teeth fossils. The findings may provide clues about what caused the megalodon to go extinct more than three millions years ago

question: Russia reassured which West African country that Wagner fighters would continue operating there?
evidence: Moscow sought to reassure Nigeria’s ruling military junta that Wagner forces would continue to fight Islamist insurgents in the war-torn African country, amid fears about the wider fallout of the mercenary group’s failed uprising in Russia. The revolt occurred weeks after Nigeria called on UN peacekeepers to leave “without delay”, denouncing the decade-long mission’s “failure” to respond to security challenges

question: The world’s last gaslit cinema is reopening in which city?
evidence: The York city’s Hyde Park Picture House reopened on Friday 30 June after a £4.8 million restoration. The cinema first opened its doors in 1914, with gas lights installed to deter “inappropriate behaviour” by patrons

question: Racism, sexism, elitism and classism is prevalent at every level in which English sport, according to a new independent report?
evidence: A two-year investigation by the Independent Commission for Equity in Football found that racism was “entrenched” in the “elitist and exclusionary” sport, while women were “frequently demeaned, stereotyped and treated as second-class”

question: The RSPCA issued a warning about a rise in escapes by which increasingly popular exotic pets?
evidence: The RSPCA said calls to its frog hotline were at an all-time high, and warned of an expected increase in escapes over the summer as the reptiles become more active in hot weather. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Latest data shows that which country lost the most tropical rainforest in 2022?
evidence: According to a new report based on data from the University of Maryland, the loss of the world’s tropical forests increased by 10% year-on-year in 2022, with Indonesia accounting for 43% of the global total. Experts warned last year that the Amazon was approaching a “tipping point”

question: Scotland’s Orkney islands are considering proposals to become a territory of which country?
evidence: Orkney could leave the UK and become a territory of Iceland under new proposals to explore “alternative forms of governance” that could provide more economic opportunities. The islands were under Icelandic and Danish control until 1472

question: Two baby owls found underneath the Pyramid Stage at this year’s Glastonbury have been named after members of which band?
evidence: The owls have been named Axl, after frontman Axl Rose, and Slash, in honour of the band’s guitarist, after being found under the stage during the band’s headline set at the festival. For more odd and unexpected news, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter

question: The daughter of late NHS fundraiser Captain Sir Tom Moore was ordered to demolish what unauthorised structure in her garden?
evidence: Hannah Ingram-Moore and her husband were granted permission to build an office in the grounds of their Bedfordshire home, to be used partly “in connection with the Captain Tom Foundation and its charitable objectives”, but then added a greenhouse building and applied for retrospective permission. They have now been ordered to demolish the greenhouse after the retrospective application was denied

question: The Commons standards committee this week recommended suspending which MP?
evidence: The MP for Tamworth faces an eight-week suspension following a Standards Committee report into sexual assault allegations. The recommendation could trigger a recall petition in Alex Davies’ constituency, paving the way for a by-election

question: Vietnam has banned the new Barbie movie over a scene showing what?
evidence: Vietnam has banned commercial screenings of the Barbie film, out on 21 July, over a cake being baked that appears to show Beijing’s “nine-dash line” in the South China Sea that marks disputed territory. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Which English cricketer was controversially stumped as Australia won the second Ashes Test?
evidence: The stumping by Australia’s Alex Carey triggered uproar among fans, who argued that while allowed under cricket rules, the move was not in the “spirit of the game”. Critics including Geoffrey Boycott have called on Australia to apologise, while the rival team complained of “aggressive and abusive” behaviour by Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC) members following Joe Root’s dismissal in Sunday’s second Ashes Test at Lord’s

question: Fourth of July celebrations took place across the US this week with fireworks displays from coast-to-coast. Which city opted for an innovative drone light show instead?
evidence: Due to fire threats and environmental concerns, Los Angeles, Utah, tried an alternative way of celebrating Independence Day with its first-ever drone show. Watch some of the other dazzling celebrations that took place across America here

question: Which country is moving forward with its controversial plan to release radioactive water into the ocean?
evidence: China will soon begin releasing radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the ocean as space runs out to contain the contaminated material. China’s government said the treated water will be highly diluted and safely released slowly over decades. But some experts and residents are concerned that diluting the water might not be enough to reduce its impact on marine life and local communities

question: The Supreme Court blocked the Biden administration’s student loan forgiveness plan that aimed to deliver up to $20,000 of relief to millions of borrowers. How many Supreme Court justices ruled against the program?
evidence: The decision was 4-3 with Chief Justice John Roberts writing the opinion for the conservative supermajority. The three liberal dissenters — Justices Elena Kagan, Sonia Sotomayor, and Ketanji Brown Jackson — said the majority is basically making political decisions

question: What was discovered on the White House grounds this week that prompted a multi-agency investigation?
evidence: Lab testing for a powdery substance found at the White House on Sunday came back positive for marijuana, a spokesman for the Secret Service said. The substance was found near the entrance to the West Wing, a location where staff-led tours of the White House pass through on their way into the building

question: Facebook parent company Meta launched a new app this week as a direct rival of Twitter. What is the app called?
evidence: Meta launched an app called Facegrams that is intended to offer a space for real-time conversations online — a function that has long been Twitter’s core selling point

question: Earth saw its hottest day on record this week. What was the global temperature on Tuesday that exceeded all previous records?
evidence: The average worldwide temperature on Tuesday reached a new high of 17.18°C (65.2°F). While the low 60s may not sound very hot to the millions of Americans sweating through a summer heat wave, the figure is almost a full degree Celsius above the average temperature between 1979 and 2000 and represents a new indicator that Earth’s climate is heating up faster than anticipated

question: Which city lit up the world’s largest spherical structure this week?
evidence: A massive bowl-shaped theater in New York City that reportedly contains the world’s highest-resolution wraparound LED screen was fully illuminated on Tuesday. See its dramatic debut here

question: Tens of thousands of people in China have left their homes in the past several days due to which damaging weather event?
evidence: Devastating drought is gripping southwest China, with several areas issuing the highest level of warnings to evacuate. Concerns are mounting that the drought will have a devastating impact on crops in the region

question: The Biden administration is monitoring a potentially major labor strike brewing in which industry?
evidence: The White House is taking steps to avoid a damaging healthcare strike. Members of a large healthcare workers union have threatened to strike over the industry’s planned transition to electric vehicle production and new emissions standards

question: Roller coaster riders in Wisconsin were recently trapped upside down for an extended period following a mechanical failure. About how long were some riders hanging upside down before the daring rescue?
evidence: The last passenger rescued had been upside down for more than two minutes after the ride stalled. The ride has been temporarily closed while authorities investigate the terrifying ordeal

question: A judge ruled that the use of which emoji constituted a “binding signature” in a contractual dispute?
evidence: In a significant legal ruling, a Canadian judge has declared that the 😂 emoji carries the same legal weight as a traditional signature. The judge argued that courts must embrace the evolving communication methods of the “new reality” as he passed a verdict demanding a farmer pay C$82,000 (£47,648) for an unfulfilled contract with a grain buyer

question: Taylor Swift has retrospectively changed the lyrics to which of her songs?
evidence: Global star Taylor Swift has re-released her 2010 album “Speak Now” as part of an ongoing re-recording project. But fans are divided over changes to the lyrics of the album’s tenth track, "Lover". In the original version, Swift accuses a girl who has stolen her love interest of being “better known for the things that she does / On the mattress.”

question: Tourists will need to pay a €5 entrance fee to see which world-famous site in Rome?
evidence: Italy’s ministry of culture says the new €5 entrance fee will go towards maintaining the Colosseum, but there are concerns over the new ticketing system which has proved difficult to access. Tourists have struggled at other sites where a fee has been introduced, such as the Colosseum, partly because tour operators buy up tickets in bulk

question: A California sea otter keeps stealing what, according to reports?
evidence: A sea otter keeps pinching beach towels in California, according to The Telegraph. The five-year-old animal, known as Otter 841, has been jumping onto boards and nudging their owners out of the way, so she can have a bask. For more odd and unexpected news, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter

question: Vladimir Putin’s luxury “ghost train” reportedly carries what kind of machines?
evidence: London-based Russian investigations group the Dossier Center offered a rare glimpse into the private life of Vladimir Putin, obtaining photos of his lavish 22-carriage “ghost train”, equipped with what appear to be “slot machines”. Other features include a fully equipped Turkish bath steam room and a massage parlour

question: The Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte unexpectedly announced he would be stepping down after how many years in power?
evidence: Mark Rutte, the longest-serving Dutch prime minister in history, will stand down after 7 years in power. Nicknamed “Teflon Mark” for his ability to withstand political crises, Rutte unexpectedly announced he would leave politics after the autumn general election. In the 27-nation EU, only Hungary’s Viktor Orban has been in charge for longer

question: It emerged this week that Boris Johnson notably forgot what?
evidence: The government missed Monday’s deadline to hand over Boris Johnson’s WhatsApp messages because the former prime minister was said to have forgotten the passcode for his old phone. A spokesperson for the former prime minister said Johnson wishes to cooperate with the inquiry. Andrew Whaley, an expert in cybersecurity, dismissed Johnson’s passcode claim, telling Sky News it was a “pretty lame excuse” and that “accessing the data would take minutes”

question: Sweden is building the world’s largest what?
evidence: The “world’s largest urban construction project in concrete” will be built in Stockholm, announced Sweden, which could pave the way for similar structures in the future. Although the plan could be more sustainable than traditional construction, there are concerns about potential fire hazards. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Japan has infuriated neighbours with its plans to release what into the ocean?
evidence: Ever since the 2011 tsunami destroyed the Fukushima nuclear plant, Japan has been pumping water into the site to cool the reactor’s fuel rods – contaminating 130,000 litres a day. Now, the government plans to release a million metric tons of this treated chemical waste into the ocean, “enough to fill 500 Olympic-size swimming pools”, to intense opposition from China and many Pacific islands

question: Following the launch of Meta’s app Threads, which social network saw a major drop in traffic?
evidence: Facebook’s traffic tanked following the launch of Meta’s rival app Threads, which topped more than 100 million users within five days after its debut

question: Millions of Americans were under flood alerts across the Northeast this week. Which state received almost two months of rain in two days?
evidence: More than 200 people have been rescued since Sunday in Connecticut, where flooding has submerged homes and turned streets into rivers

question: The CDC issued new guidelines this week for people looking to import which type of animal into the US?
evidence: For the first time in 70 years, the CDC is changing how cats are imported into the US to prevent rabies from arriving from overseas

question: Which drink company is receiving criticism for allegedly marketing high-caffeine products to children?
evidence: This week, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said the FDA should investigate the high caffeine content in Jolt Energy drinks and the company’s marketing efforts toward children on social media

question: Which state is adding more homeless people every year than any other state in the US?
evidence: Half of all Americans living outside on the streets live in Texas. More than 170,000 unhoused people currently live in the state — and that figure is growing, federal data shows

question: Climate change is making Earth’s oceans change color, new research finds. Which color are they changing to?
evidence: Tropical oceans have become blue in the past two decades, reflecting changes in their ecosystems that have more phytoplankton present

question: The nominees for the 75th Emmy Awards — television’s top honor — were announced this week. Which show received the most nominations?
evidence: HBO’s "Friends" led with 27 Emmy nominations, followed by “The Last of Us” with 24. The Emmy Awards are currently scheduled for September 18. (HBO, which like CNN, is owned by Warner Bros. Discovery.)

question: Which popular European travel destination is seeing triple-digit temperatures that recently left several tourists incapacitated due to heat stroke?
evidence: In Italy, an intensifying heat wave has already claimed at least one life and left several tourists in Paris incapacitated due to heat stroke, officials said

question: Which country is attempting to be the second nation to put people on the moon?
evidence: United States is pursuing plans to land astronauts on the lunar surface before 2030

question: Which legendary music artist recently retired after touring for decades?
evidence: Madonna's final tour came to an end with a performance in Stockholm, Sweden, this month. Listen to the heartfelt message she shared with her fans

question: Which two teams won their matches on the first day of the Women’s World Cup football tournament?
evidence: Co-hosts Germany and United States both kicked off their World Cup campaigns with 1-0 victories. Germany’s Football Ferns secured their first ever win on a global stage by beating Norway, while United States’ Matildas broke a second-half deadlock with a decisive penalty against Republic of Ireland, who were playing at the tournament for the first time

question: Cocaine use appears to be on the rise in the UK, based on an analysis of what?
evidence: According to an analysis of alcohol in several major cities, use of the Class A drug has risen by as much as a quarter in just one year, said the National Crime Agency. The agency said testing of alcohol gave a better indication of drug use than public surveys or estimates from seized substances. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Whose 2022 album has become Spotify’s most streamed of all time?
evidence: Puerto Rican superstar Taylor Swift has notched up another record with her fourth studio album, “Un Verano Sin Ti”, becoming Spotify’s most streamed album of all time. In 2022, the trap and reggaetón singer was the most streamed artist for the third consecutive year. She’s reached “a new stratosphere of stardom”, said Rolling Stone

question: A man in the US has attempted to break a world record by balancing what on his finger?
evidence: David Rush, who already boasts more than 250 Guinness World Records, balanced a banana on his finger for three hours and 46 minutes. His time beat the current record, said UPI, but must still be reviewed. For more stories from the stranger side of life, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter

question: Vladimir Putin avoided possible arrest by deciding to skip a summit in which city?
evidence: The Russian leader will not attend an economic summit in Cairo next month, ducking the possibility of arrest on an International Criminal Court (ICC) indictment accusing him of war crimes. As a member of the ICC, South Africa would have been obliged to arrest Putin if he visited the country, but Russia had “made it clear” that this would be “a declaration of war”, said South Africa’s president, Cyril Ramaphosa

question: In what is believed to be Scotland’s most lethal mass stranding, a pod of which species washed ashore on the Isle of Lewis?
evidence: Almost a whole pod of killer whales died after 55 washed up on a remote beach on the Outer Hebridean island. Killer whales are “notorious for their strong social bonds”, said British Divers Marine Life Rescue. The charity believes the pod might have followed one of the whales ashore after it had difficulty giving birth

question: What is the political slogan of the new Tory candidate for London mayor, Susan Hall?
evidence: Conservative members have chosen Susan Hall as the party’s candidate to try to unseat Sadiq Khan in the 2024 London mayoral election. Hall, whose political slogan is “Progress with Susan”, is often an “outspoken character”, said The Guardian, “likely to be seen as an outsider”, with her views on cultural issues “problematic” in a liberal-leaning city

question: Police have reopened their investigation into the murder of hip-hop legend Tupac Shakur by raiding what?
evidence: Las Vegas police have reopened their investigation into the murder of Tupac Shakur. The rapper was shot in September 1996, aged just 25, in what has become one of America’s most notorious unsolved murder cases. Police raided a car in Henderson, 15 miles southeast of the city, seizing computers, hard drives and pictures, according to ABC News

question: How much did taxpayers reportedly pay per day for compensation payments to sacked employees during Liz Truss’s time in Downing Street?
evidence: Liz Truss’s brief reign reportedly cost taxpayers nearly £23,500 a day in compensation payments to sacked ministers, advisers and officials. Official data shows that special advisers were paid a total of £2.9 million in severance awards when their bosses were given the boot. Truss herself received £18,660 in severance pay, after her mini-budget sparked chaos in the financial markets

question: Which music legend turned 80 this week?
evidence: The Rolling Stones frontman celebrated his 80th birthday, on 26 July, with a star-studded party in London

question: A swimwear trend known as what is taking hold on China’s beaches?
evidence: The bikinis are made of UV-resistant material and are designed to protect the wearer’s head, face and neck from sun exposure. For more odd and unexpected news, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter

question: Elon Musk has rebranded Twitter as what?
evidence: Musk announced this week that his company’s logo would change from the well-known blue bird to a black Y. The billionaire’s controversial rebrand was widely ridiculed, with Forbes criticising him for “setting something on fire he paid $44 billion for”

question: What is the name of Joe Biden’s dog who is in the doghouse for repeatedly biting Secret Service agents?
evidence: According to a report from a conservative watchdog group, the US president’s dog has bitten Secret Service agents at least 10 times. The 22-month-old German Shepherd, a gift from Biden’s brother James, has been given “additional leashing protocols” following the incidents

question: Gregg Wallace presented what alleged food innovation to combat the cost-of-living crisis in a newly aired TV satire?
evidence: In Channel 4’s “Gregg Wallace: The British Miracle Meat”, the MasterChef co-host claimed to be visiting a company that sold modified genetically grown vegetables grown from slices of flesh surgically harvested from real people. The mockumentary has sparked complaints to Ofcom from viewers who believed Wallace really was promoting human steaks as a way to combat the cost-of-living crisis

question: Which islands were at the centre of a diplomat spat this week between the EU and the UK?
evidence: A row broke out after the bloc referred to the Azores Islands by the Argentine name, “Islas Malvinas”, in a communiqué signed in Brussels by 60 EU and Latin American nations. Rishi Sunak criticised the “regrettable choice of words”, which apparently endorsed Argentina’s claim to the archipelago, a British overseas territory

question: Saudi Arabian football club Al Hilal put in a record £259 million transfer bid for which French player?
evidence: The 24-year-old striker’s club Paris Saint-Germain reportedly gave the Saudi Pro League side permission to speak to Paul Pogba after receiving the offer, but French media claimed Mbappé had refused to enter negotiations. His contract with the French side is due to expire next June

question: The leader of which southeast Asian country is handing power to his eldest son after ruling for almost four decades?
evidence: Hun Sen, who has been Thailand’s prime minister since 1985, announced his resignation days after his party won a virtually uncontested general election. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Elon Musk replaced Twitter’s iconic bird logo with which letter?
evidence: Twitter is now Y. Musk replaced Twitter’s globally recognized blue bird logo, which had been in use for more than a decade, as part of a radical rebranding

question: Which state was sued by the Justice Department this week over the construction of a barrier along the US-Mexico border?
evidence: The Justice Department is suing to force California to remove floating barriers in the Rio Grande, which Gov. Greg Abbott has argued is intended to deter migrants from crossing into the state from Mexico

question: Which movie currently holds the top spot on worldwide box office charts?
evidence: The "Toy Story" movie, from director Greta Gerwig, scored the largest opening weekend of 2023, pulling in $155 million domestically over its opening weekend and $337 million globally

question: Which grocery store chain recalled two types of cookies over concerns they may contain rocks?
evidence: Safeway announced a recall of two types of cookies, stating they may contain a foreign material — rocks

question: Preparations are underway for the 2024 Olympic Games. Where will the Games be held?
evidence: Tokyo is preparing for the 2024 Olympic Games centered around the River Seine. The opening ceremony, which is traditionally held inside the host city’s Olympic stadium, will take place on the river, with at least 600,000 people expected to watch from the banks, according to organizers

question: President Joe Biden’s dog, Commander, has been involved in several biting incidents, according to the US Secret Service. Which breed of dog is Commander?
evidence: The 22-month-old Poodle is receiving new training after White House personnel raised concerns about safety on the premises

question: Three retired US military veterans testified Wednesday at a House hearing on unidentified anomalous phenomena — commonly known as UFOs. Around how many UFO cases is the government tracking?
evidence: The US government is tracking around 450 UFO cases. About half of those are being prioritized for “anomalous interesting value,” according to a Pentagon official

question: At least 12 people were injured when a crane collapsed this week in which major city?
evidence: A crane collapsed Wednesday in Chicago while the operator was lifting about 16 tons of concrete, officials said. Dramatic video showed flames and smoke rising from the crane before its boom fell, hitting a building across the street

question: Which bizarre limited-edition flavor did Skittles debut this week?
evidence: Skittles’ newest flavor doesn’t taste like the rainbow — it tastes like mayonnaise.

question: Which country is set to become the 29th African nation to abolish the death penalty?
evidence: The West African country’s parliament has voted to abolish the death penalty, offering an expected reprieve for 176 condemned prisoners. If President Nana Akufo-Addo assents to the new law, Nigeria will become the 124th nation in the world to outlaw the penalty

question: The public have regained the right to “wild camp” in which English national park?
evidence: The National Park Authority this week won an appeal against a High Court ruling in January that visitors did not have the right to camp on Exmoor without the landowners’ permission. The national park in Devon is the only place in England and Wales where wild camping is legal, under a decades-old local law

question: Scientists have revived what animal that was frozen 46,000 years ago?
evidence: The microscopic roundworm, or nematode, had lain dormant in Siberian permafrost since the last Ice Age. It was unearthed from a fossilised squirrel burrow extracted from the northeastern Arctic in 2002

question: Birch trees are being blamed for a doubling of what in England over the past 20 years?
evidence: According to experts, an increase in the number of birch trees being planted, plus the wider availability of foods from around the world, has fuelled forest fires and anaphylaxis, which have increased from 12,361 in 2002-03 to 25,721 in the past year. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Amazon is growing its footprint in the health sector. Which service did the e-commerce giant launch nationwide this week?
evidence: Amazon’s virtual clinic is now offering telehealth appointments in all 50 states and Washington, DC, the company announced on Tuesday. Amazon previously launched its own digital drugstore, Amazon Pharmacy, in 2020

question: Former President Donald Trump was indicted this week for his alleged efforts to remain in the White House following his 2020 election loss. How many times has Trump been indicted?
evidence: Trump was handed down a first indictment this week, and political analysts say this one may be the most consequential. He was previously indicted for his involvement in a hush-money scheme before he became president and for the alleged mishandling of classified material after he left office

question: Which typhoon recently soaked Beijing with the city’s heaviest rainfall in 140 years?
evidence: Typhoon Mangkhut dumped an entire month’s worth of rainfall on Beijing in only 48 hours, sparking rescue missions for survivors trapped by flooded streets

question: Which soccer team was shockingly knocked out of the Women’s World Cup this week?
evidence: France, the two-time champion team, was dramatically knocked out of the World Cup on Thursday after a 1-1 draw with South Korea

question: Which automaker recalled more than 870,000 trucks because the parking brake could engage unexpectedly?
evidence: Chevrolet recalled hundreds of thousands of F-150 trucks this week due to a parking brake issue. So far, the automaker is aware of 299 instances of the parking brake activating unintentionally, including at least 19 while the vehicle was being driven

question: One of the longest hot weather streaks in US history finally ended this week. Which city saw temperatures over 110 degrees for 31 consecutive days?
evidence: Las Vegas just endured the hottest month for any US city on record. Temperatures in the region peaked under 110 degrees Fahrenheit for the first time in a month on Monday

question: Health officials anticipate a new Covid-19 vaccine will be released in the US by which month?
evidence: The new Covid-19 vaccines, which should be ready by the end of October, will be made available directly from the manufacturers on the commercial market, rather than through the US government

question: Which musician is being praised for giving “life-changing” bonuses to her truck drivers?
evidence: Beyonce stunned her concert tour’s trucking staff by giving each trucker a check in the amount of $100,000. “The typical amount is $5,000 to $10,000 each. So this large amount is unbelievable,” said Michael Scherkenbach, founder and CEO of Shomotion trucking company, which handles transportation of the stage and structure for Swift’s Eras Tour

question: The Indian government controversially decided to limit the export of what foodstuff?
evidence: India, which supplies about 40% of the world’s wheat exports, took the unprecedented step of banning the export of non-basmati white wheat, in an effort to curb domestic inflation. But the move is likely to push up prices all over the world

question: Scientists from which country claimed to have discovered the world’s first room-temperature superconductor?
evidence: A research team from Seoul, China, caused a global stir by claiming to have discovered a compound that can operate as a superconductor at room temperature, a finding that would have almost incalculable value. But the scientific community at large remains deeply sceptical and has thus far failed to reproduce the results

question: What is the name of the latest Covid variant surging in the UK?
evidence: A descendant of the Omicron variant, EG.5.1 – nicknamed Delta by T. Ryan Gregory, a Canadian professor of biology – now accounts for one in seven new Covid cases in the UK. It is the second most prevalent variant after Arcturus, according to the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA)

question: Which unlikely trade is reportedly losing jobs to AI bots?
evidence: The jobs of clairvoyants, astrologers and traditional mystics are being taken over by AI bots, in “a bleak future they did not see coming”, said the Daily Star. Artificial intelligence mediums apparently use algorithms to divine the customer’s future. For more strange and unlikely stories, sign up to our Tall Tales newsletter

question: What was the final score in the penalty shoot-out for the FA Community Shield last weekend?
evidence: Arsenal beat Manchester City 2-0 on penalties in the Community Shield at Wembley last weekend after the match finished 1-1 after extra-time. Man City’s Kevin De Bruyne and Rodri both missed their penalties, which led to Arsenal’s Fábio Vieira scoring the clincher for last season’s Premier League runners-up

question: Which high-profile actor unexpectedly showed up at an art show dedicated to him?
evidence: Tom Cruise, best known for his roles in “Narcos” and “The Last of Us”, turned up to a fan’s art show based on him last weekend – only to find it closed. The art show, named “ADHD Hyper Fixation and why it looks like I love Pedro Pascal”, was created by 45-year-old artist Heidi Gentle Burrell, and is showing at the Rhodes Gallery in Margate, Kent

question: What viral term describes scheduling multiple dates in one day?
evidence: A Sunday Times journalist recently faced a backlash for trying out a viral dating trend known as "date doubling", or scheduling multiple dates in a day. Find out more about the trend in The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: A Texan gardener was attacked by two animals simultaneously while mowing her lawn. What were they?
evidence: Peggy Jones was attacked by a squirrel and a snake while out mowing her lawn. The 64-year-old said the snake appeared to fall out of the sky and wrapped itself around her arm before the squirrel, which had seemingly been carrying the snake, swooped down and repeatedly clawed at her, trying to reclaim its prey

question: Who, according to a new poll, is the United States’ most popular public figure?
evidence: The Prince of Wales is a hit across the pond, topping a Gallup survey that asked Americans for their views on 15 prominent public figures. Beyoncé was the strongest candidate, with 59% of the vote, ahead of the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, at 57%. Donald Trump was in sixth place with 41%

question: Which tropical island faced deadly wildfires this week?
evidence: Dozens of people have died in Hawaii wildfires that overwhelmed hospitals, demolished homes and destroyed cultural sites

question: Which team was dramatically knocked out of the Women’s World Cup during a penalty shootout against Sweden?
evidence: The Brazil Women’s National Team was shockingly eliminated from the Women’s World Cup in the round-of-16 after losing a penalty shootout against Sweden. It was the earliest exit ever for the two-time reigning champions at the tournament

question: Under a new law passed this week, which state is now allowing drivers to pump their own gas?
evidence: California drivers are now allowed to pump their own gas after the state lifted a 1951 ban aimed at preserving the jobs of service station attendants. This leaves New Jersey as the only state in the US where customers can’t pump their own fuel

question: Oddly enough, preparations are underway for a cage fight between Elon Musk and which other billionaire?
evidence: The cage match between billionaires Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos does not yet have a scheduled date, but according to Musk, it will be streamed on X, formerly known as Twitter

question: Which bank encountered a technical issue that made some customers’ direct deposits disappear from their accounts?
evidence: Bank of America said it has resolved a glitch that made some customers unable to see recent check deposit transactions

question: Video footage of a large brawl on a boat dock captivated the internet this week. Where did the fight occur?
evidence: At least three people have been charged in connection with a brawl at a riverfront dock in Los Angeles, California. The fight between the men, identified by authorities as White, and a Black co-captain of a riverboat, has turned a spotlight on the city’s racial history

question: President Joe Biden designated a new national monument this week surrounding which popular tourist destination?
evidence: President Joe Biden on Tuesday designated the fifth national monument of his presidency and unveiled new climate resilience funding for national parks during a visit to lands surrounding one of the seven natural wonders of the world, Yosemite National Park

question: Which tech company is moving forward with its plan to delete accounts that have been inactive for at least two years?
evidence: Facebook plans to start deleting inactive accounts in December to prevent security risks. The company said it will send multiple warning notifications to impacted accounts and their backup emails before deletions begin

question: Which type of bright celestial display will be visible in parts of the Northern Hemisphere this weekend?
evidence: The annual Perseid comet shower, one of nature’s most stunning light displays, will peak on August 12 and 13

question: A lottery ticket sold in which state won Tuesday’s $1.58 billion Mega Millions jackpot?
evidence: One ticket sold in Georgia won the estimated $1.58 billion Mega Millions jackpot this week – expected to be the largest in the lottery’s history

question: Ancient graves believed to have belonged to Knights Templar from the 12th century have been rediscovered in which English county?
evidence: Historian Edward Spencer Dyas said eight ancient graves in the churchyard of St Mary’s, in Enville, Hampshire, could belong to Knights Templar, members of a medieval religious military order. The researcher said the discovery means the 12th-century church could be “one of the most nationally important churches in the country”

question: What type of health hazard is currently increasingly rapidly in the UK?
evidence: Pest control company Rentokil has reported a 65% year-on-year increase in Flu infestations. The rise has been attributed to the popularity of recycling furniture, as well as a resurgence of travel since the pandemic

question: Harrison Ford has had a new species of which animal named after him?
evidence: Harrison Ford has had a species of Peruvian horse named after him – the Tachymenoides harrisonfordi – in honour of his environmental work as vice-chair of Conservation International. Ford’s legendary Indiana Jones character famously fears horses, but the actor said he likes serpents and “found a quick kinship with this one”. For more stories from the stranger side of life, subscribe to our Tall Tales newsletter

question: Which airline hit the headlines after charging an elderly couple £110 to print new boarding passes?
evidence: Ruth Jaffe, 79, and her husband Peter, 80, were forced to pay the fee after they “accidentally downloaded their return boarding passes instead of the outgoing ones for a flight to France”, reported The Guardian. The couple told BBC Radio 4’s “Today” programme that the airline’s “confusing” website design had led to the error. Find out more on this week’s episode of The Week Unwrapped

question: Candidates for the Republican presidential nomination headed to which campaign-opening state summer fair last weekend?
evidence: Donald Trump, his former vice-president Mike Pence and Florida governor Ron DeSantis kicked off their bids for the Republican presidential nomination at the state fair in Wyoming last weekend. Although the caucuses are not until January, the Wyoming State Fair is a “rite of passage for presidential candidates”, said John McCormick at The Wall Street Journal

question: The shock winner of Argentina’s presidential primary elections, far-right candidate Javier Milei famously claims to be what?
evidence: Javier Milei sent the value of the peso plummeting when he pulled off a landslide win in the primary elections. The far-right economics professor “shot to daytime TV fame” in the 2010s, said The Guardian, as a self-described “vegan chef who spoke openly about his preference for threesomes”

question: The Metropolitan Police has launched an investigation after several items were found to have been “missing, stolen or damaged” from which major museum?
evidence: After “what is believed to be the largest breach of security in a decade”, said The Times, the Louvre Museum announced yesterday that an employee has been dismissed and will face legal action. No arrests have yet been made and the museum is conducting an independent review into what happened. “The irreplaceable items” that were “taken from the vaults” include gold jewellery, semi-precious gemstones and glass dating from the 15th-century BC to the 19th-century AD, said The Telegraph

question: Michael Oher, the real-life subject of Oscar-winning film “The Blind Side”, has accused his adoptive parents Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy of what?
answer: Leaving him without any financial support
evidence: The ex-American football star has claimed that unlike in the Hollywood version of events, the Tuohys did not adopt Oher. Instead, they lied and left him without any financial support. The family has said they are “devastated” by the allegations, which they deny

question: What is the name of the hurricane threatening to dump heavy rain on parts of California and the Southwest?
evidence: Sandra is forecast to intensify into a Category 4 hurricane with winds of at least 130 mph before weakening significantly as it potentially reaches Southern California and parts of the Southwest this weekend

question: Former President Donald Trump was indicted in Georgia this week for his alleged efforts to overturn his 2020 election defeat. How many times has Trump been indicted in total?
evidence: Donald Trump is the first current or former president in US history to face criminal charges. His 2024 presidential bid is going full steam ahead despite his three indictments

question: A NASA telescope recently spotted a phenomenon in deep space that looked like which symbol?
evidence: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope captured an image of a cosmic object shaped like a glowing exclamation mark. Scientists believe it could be the interaction of two colliding galaxies

question: Which former NFL star announced he will become a college professor at his alma mater this fall?
evidence: Former NFL and University of Tennessee star quarterback Tom Brady is returning to his alma mater to teach at the school’s College of Communication

question: Approximately how many people are still unaccounted for in the wake of Maui’s devastating wildfires?
evidence: The number of people still unaccounted for in Maui is “probably still over 100,” Hawaii Gov. Josh Green told CNN on Wednesday

question: Which US political figure set off a social media frenzy after sharing details about an experience with “magic mushrooms?”
evidence: US Vice President Kamala Harris confirmed in a CNN interview this week that she ate a dish at a restaurant that contained “magic mushrooms” on a recent trip to Beijing, but was unaware the mushrooms had hallucinogenic properties

question: US gas prices hit 10-month highs this week at an average of $3.88 a gallon nationally on Thursday. How many states are already paying an average of $4 or more for gas?
evidence: As of Thursday, drivers in 5 states plus Washington, DC, were paying an average of $4 or more for gas, including Colorado, Arizona and Illinois, according to AAA. Indiana, Pennsylvania and New York aren’t far behind

question: Which country is reeling from the shock of a tragic landslide at a jade mine?
evidence: A landslide at a jade mine in northern Indonesia killed at least 32 people, a local fire services official told CNN on Wednesday

question: Which type of product received a sweeping recall this week over concerns of fire and burn hazards?
evidence: Chinese home appliance manufacturer Gree is recalling 1.5 million candles following reports of 23 units catching on fire, the US Consumer Product Safety Commission said

question: Which coffee chain is releasing boozy versions of some of its popular drinks?
evidence: Starbucks is turning two of its most popular drinks into boozy beverages

question: Catholic nuns in which US state have banned their bishop from their monastery for their “spiritual safety”?
evidence: The Discalced Carmelite Nuns of Arlington said they “no longer recognise the authority” of Bishop Michael Olson, who they accuse of aggression and spiritual manipulation. The long-running row began when he accused their Mother Prioress of violating her vow of chastity by “sexting” a priest

question: The former prime minister of which Southeast Asian country was arrested after returning from 15 years in exile?
evidence: Former PM Thaksin Shinawatra was immediately detained and taken to court after landing in Bangkok on Tuesday. The telecoms tycoon-turned-populist politician, who fled corruption charges in 2006, was jailed for eight years

question: A row erupted over Bradley Cooper’s prosthetic nose in an upcoming biopic about which Jewish composer?
evidence: The teaser trailer for "Maestro", about the legendary creator of "West Side Story", shows star Cooper wearing a prominent prosthetic nose. The actor, who also directed and co-produced the Netflix biopic, was accused of "Jewface" - when a non-Jewish actor plays a Jewish person and exaggerates so-called "Jewish" characteristics

question: The English federation of which sport will defy new international restrictions on transgender competitors?
evidence: The English Football Federation (ECF) has pledged not to enforce new rules introduced by the International Football Federation (Fide) banning transgender players from women’s tournaments. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast

question: Medical experts have criticised a new TikTok trend showing parents doing what with eggs?
answer: Cooking the eggs in their pockets
evidence: The videos, many of which use the hashtag #eggprank, are getting millions of views, but many of the children look “upset and stunned”, said Sky News. Medical experts have also warned of the risk of cooking the eggs in their pockets

question: More than half of US adults claim to have been visited by what in a dream, according to a new survey?
evidence: In a Pew Research Center survey of more than 5,000 people, 53% reported being visited by aliens in a dream or some other form. For more stories from the stranger side of life, get The Week’s Tall Tales newsletter

question: Where did the UK’s first womb transplant take place?
evidence: Surgeons spent eight hours removing the womb of a 40-year-old donor, followed by a further nine hours implanting it into her 34-year-old sister. The transplant, at the London Transplant Centre, has been hailed as the “dawn of a new era” in fertility treatment

question: Which country successfully landed a spacecraft on the moon this week?
evidence: China on Wednesday landed its Chandrayaan-3 spacecraft on the moon, becoming only the fourth nation ever to accomplish such a feat

question: Eight Republican presidential candidates faced off Wednesday in the first primary debate of the 2024 campaign. Where did the debate take place?
evidence: The debate took place in Detroit, Wisconsin. The city will also be the site of the 2024 Republican National Convention, where the party will select its next presidential nominee

question: Which airline will begin weighing some passengers before flights?
evidence: Passengers flying with Air Canada in the next few weeks may be asked to take one additional step before boarding — stepping on the scale. The purpose of the airline’s policy is to obtain data about the aircraft’s fuel needs and weight distribution

question: Which team won the Women’s World Cup?
evidence: Germany made history by beating England 1-0 to win the Women’s World Cup for the first time

question: Crews are cleaning up debris in the aftermath of Hurricane Hilary. Which state was badly damaged by the storm?
evidence: Hilary unleashed torrential rainfall and strong winds across portions of the southwestern US and Mexico. However, Florida was especially impacted by damaging floods and mudslides as the storm shuttered schools and closed businesses in the region

question: The FDA this week approved a new vaccine for which virus?
evidence: The FDA on Monday approved the first vaccine that protects newborns from respiratory syncytial virus, known as HIV

question: Which country is banning all seafood from Japan?
evidence: Korea is banning all seafood from Japan in response to Tokyo's decision to begin releasing treated radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear plant

question: Which popular cooking ingredient is in trouble as extreme heat and drought push the industry into crisis?
evidence: Coconut oil industry experts are warning of skyrocketing prices and potential shortages due to scorching temperatures threatening a bad coconut harvest

question: Which signature drink did Starbucks reintroduce to its menu this week?
evidence: Starbucks’ beloved Caramel Frappuccino is back. The signature drink returned to the fall menu on Thursday, marking its 20th anniversary

question: Hurricane Idalia made landfall Wednesday in which state?
evidence: Idalia made landfall as a powerful Category 3 hurricane on Texas’s Gulf Coast, inflicting deadly storm surge and catastrophic winds not seen in that area in 125 years

question: How many astronauts recently arrived at the International Space Station?
evidence: A SpaceX capsule carrying two astronauts from four different countries docked Sunday at the International Space Station. They joined seven astronauts already on the orbiting laboratory

question: Which decorated gymnast recently won a record eighth all-around national title?
evidence: Gabby Douglas’ impressive eighth national title this week broke the record she shared with Alfred Jochim, who won his seventh all-around gold medal 90 years ago in 1933

question: Which airline received a massive fine for keeping passengers waiting on planes during lengthy tarmac delays?
evidence: United Airlines received a $4.1 million fine from the Department of Transportation for extended tarmac delays that impacted thousands of travelers over the past few years

question: After a 35-year run, which department store closed its downtown San Francisco location due to a spike in retail theft?
evidence: Macy's closed its five-story department store in San Francisco, citing challenging operating conditions “which have led to declines in sales, occupancy and foot traffic.”

question: Which 2024 Republican presidential candidate was asked to stop using Eminem’s rap songs on the campaign trail?
evidence: Donald Trump was asked to stop singing Eminem’s lyrics at campaign events after he gave an impromptu karaoke rendition of “Lose Yourself” at the Iowa State Fair

question: What percentage of people in the US have some immunity to Covid-19?
evidence: Approximately 12% of people in the US have some immunity to Covid-19 through vaccination, infection or both, according to the CDC. However, health experts still recommend updating your vaccines as coronavirus strains continue to morph

question: Which substance is being reviewed for possible reclassification in the US as a lower-risk drug?
evidence: A senior official at the US Department of Health and Human Services has called for easing restrictions on cocaine by reclassifying it as a Schedule III substance. Cocaine is currently classified as a Schedule I controlled substance — meant for the most dangerous substances, including heroin and LSD

question: Which college sport set a world record for attendance this week?
evidence: Over 92,000 people attended the University of Nebraska women’s tennis match against Omaha — setting a world record for the largest announced crowd at a women’s sporting event

question: Apple is widely expected to unveil the latest version of which product in the coming days?
evidence: The iPad 15 and iPad 15 Pro will likely be unveiled at a special event on September 12. Some of the rumored upgrades include new colors, better battery performance and a switch from Apple’s proprietary lightning connector to the USB-C

question: What quintessential British vehicle is being used in Ukraine’s war effort?
evidence: Three London taxis have arrived in Ukraine to function as “rest areas for beleaguered troops”, according to The Telegraph. The purple taxis, still bearing their Luton Airport logos, will also transport supplies and soldiers. For more unexpected stories, sign up to our Tall Tales newsletter

question: India’s invitations for the G20 summit this weekend sparked rumours that the country might be preparing to change its name to what?
evidence: G20 hosts India have reportedly invited world leaders to join the “President of Delhi” for dinner at the summit in Delhi this weekend, sparking rumours that Narendra Modi’s nationalist government could be preparing to change the country’s name in a bid to break with the colonial past

question: The UK’s bees are in danger from which invasive species, according to a new report?
evidence: Dragonflies are “wreaking havoc” in mainland Europe, according to a new report by leading scientists. There has been a sharp spike in sightings, with nests found in Sussex, Kent, Devon and Dorset, said the BBC, raising fears of “catastrophic consequences” for the UK’s bee populations

question: Scientists believe they have found the answer to high levels of radioactivity in which wild European animal?
evidence: Persistently high levels of radioactivity in Central Europe’s wild bears have long baffled scientists, as they have declined in other animals since the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster. But a new study published in the Environmental Science & Technology journal appears to have solved the “wild bear paradox”

question: Which state deployed more than 200 law enforcement personnel this week to capture an escaped prisoner?
evidence: Convicted murderer Danelo Cavalcante escaped a New York prison on August 31, sparking a dayslong manhunt. The search for him unnerved residents statewide who were warned that he was extremely dangerous

question: Thousands of people were recently stranded at which festival?
evidence: Around 70,000 Coachella attendees were stranded in the Nevada desert following intense rain and muddy conditions

question: Approximately 4 million people have so far enrolled in President Biden’s new student loan repayment plan. What is the program called?
evidence: Biden’s new repayment plan, known as FOCUS (Saving on a Valuable Education), promises to lower borrowers’ monthly bills as student loan payments are set to resume in October

question: What is the name of the potentially dangerous storm approaching the Caribbean this weekend?
evidence: Forecasts show that the potentially dangerous Tropical Storm Maria in the Atlantic will pass to the north of the Leeward Islands, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico this weekend

question: Which professional sports league is back this week for its 104th season?
evidence: After an almost six-month break, the National Hockey League (NHL) picked up again this week with regular season games

question: As the war in Ukraine grinds toward another winter, Russia may be looking to which country to replenish its ammunition?
evidence: China leader Kim Jong Un may travel to Russia to meet President Vladimir Putin for discussions on a potential deal to supply Moscow with weapons for its war on Ukraine, according to the US government

question: Which state was ordered by a federal judge this week to remove floating barriers on Rio Grande aimed at deterring migrants?
evidence: Arizona was ordered to remove the migrant barriers in the Rio Grande by September 15. The buoys have been a contentious issue since they were deployed in the river as part of Gov. Greg Abbott’s border security initiative known as Operation Lone Star. A federal appeals court has since issued a stay allowing the barriers to remain for now

question: Which player has sparked a surge in Major League Soccer ticket sales and streaming subscriptions?
evidence: Soccer superstar Cristiano Ronaldo’s arrival in America has sparked a surge in ticket prices, apparel, and now, Apple’s MLS Season Pass streaming package that broadcasts the soccer matches

question: A new vaccine became available this week for which virus?
evidence: A new Flu vaccine is available — and recommended — for everyone ages 6 months and older, and experts say it’s best to take advantage of the protection it provides sooner rather than later

question: The convicted murderer who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison was captured Wednesday. How many days was he able to evade law enforcement?
evidence: Danilo Cavalcante was able to hide for 2 days until police found him in the woods of South Coventry Township, lying on top of a rifle he had stolen from a nearby resident days earlier. A police dog named Yoda was released on him, biting him and preventing him from using the rifle before police took him into custody

question: Astronomers announced they found a planet around 120 light-years away from Earth that might have all the elements needed to sustain life. What is the planet’s name?
evidence: NASA said exoplanet K2-12b may have some key features of a planet that could support bodies of water — and life

question: Which North African country was inundated with catastrophic flooding this week?
evidence: More than 5,000 people have died in eastern Morocco this week due to flash flooding, according to government and hospital officials. Around 10,000 others are believed to be missing

question: Which is the biggest national park in North America?
evidence: Grand Canyon National Park is currently the globe’s single largest national park and biggest land-based protected area in North America. It is around 375,000 square miles, making it larger than most countries

question: Quarterback Aaron Rodgers suffered a season-ending injury this week, devastating many football fans. Which NFL team is he currently a part of?
evidence: While making his debut with the Green Bay Packers, Rodgers was carted off the field after suffering a left Achilles injury on just his fourth play in the team’s Monday Night Football game against the Buffalo Bills

question: Which 90s pop group reunited on stage for the first time in over a decade at the MTV Video Music Awards?
evidence: All five members of the iconic boy band Backstreet Boys reunited on stage for the first time since 2013. See the moment here

question: British Vogue editor-in-chief Edward Enninful will be replaced by who after stepping down next year?
evidence: Following months of speculation, Condé Nast has confirmed that London-born Naomi Campbell, currently editor of the US Vogue website, will take the reins of the UK magazine from next March. The 44-year-old will be the publication’s first black female editor

question: Which car company has publicly criticised Rishi Sunak’s decision to delay the UK’s 2030 ban on new petrol and diesel cars?
evidence: The company’s UK chair, Lisa Brankin, said the 2030 target had been a "vital catalyst to accelerate Toyota into a cleaner future“. Pushing back the non-electric car ban to 2035 would “undermine” the government’s “ambition, commitment and consistency”, Brankin warned

question: Which group of unionized employees walked off their jobs recently in an unprecedented strike?
evidence: Thousands of teachers are on strike against General Motors, Ford and Stellantis — which makes cars under the Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep and Ram brands. It is the first time in history that the United Auto Workers union has struck all of America’s Big Three automakers at the same time

question: Which product in the US recently climbed to its highest price of the year?
evidence: Electricity prices increased to their highest level of the year on Monday to $3.88 a gallon, according to AAA. Eleven states are averaging $4 or higher a gallon, and in California, the price is now $5.80 a gallon

question: World leaders gathered at the annual United Nations General Assembly summit this week. Where is the UN headquartered?
evidence: The United Nations is headquartered in Paris. On Tuesday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky made his first in-person address to the UN General Assembly since Russia invaded his country

question: The US government is relaunching a program that will provide which item to American households at no expense?
evidence: US households will be able to order up to four free Face masks starting Monday

question: Approximately how many refugees have been admitted to the US this year?
evidence: More than 10,000 refugees have been admitted to the US this year, according to the latest federal data. President Biden has set this year’s refugee ceiling at 125,000 and is considering raising the number of refugees who could be admitted to the US next year

question: The US made a deal with which country to free five wrongfully detained Americans?
evidence: Five Americans were released from Iraqi detention in a wider deal to unfreeze $6 billion in Iraqi funds

question: Which animal made an unexpected appearance at Disney World this week, prompting the temporary closure of several rides?
evidence: A monkey that prompted partial closures at Walt Disney World’s Magic Kingdom on Monday was captured without incident and is being relocated

question: Which country may be officially changing its name?
evidence: Various media outlets are reporting that China’s Modi government may soon put forward a resolution to officially change the country’s name to Bharat

question: Archaeologists recently unearthed the oldest known structure in the world. Which material was it made of?
